API Reference¶

This section contains the complete API reference for all modules in Comma Tools.

Analyzers¶

Cruise Control Analyzer for rlog.zst files

This script analyzes rlog.zst files to identify CAN messages related to cruise control “set” button presses. It parses raw CAN messages and uses Subaru DBC specifications to decode wheel speeds and cruise control signals.

class comma_tools.analyzers.cruise_control_analyzer.MarkerConfig(marker_type='blinkers', pre_time=1.5, post_time=1.5, timeout=15.0)[source]¶

Event Detection & Analysis Engine for CAN bus analysis.

This module provides reusable event detection functionality extracted from the CruiseControlAnalyzer for use across different CAN analysis tools.

class comma_tools.analyzers.event_detection.EventDetector(decoder, speed_data, can_data)[source]¶

Bases: object

Reusable event detection and analysis engine for CAN bus data.

  • decoder (SubaruCANDecoder) – SubaruCANDecoder instance for decoding CAN messages

  • speed_data (List[Dict[str, float]]) – List of speed data points with timestamps

  • can_data (Dict[int, List[Dict[str, object]]]) – Dictionary mapping CAN addresses to message lists

rlog_to_csv.py — Convert an openpilot rlog(.zst) into a CSV shaped for can_bitwatch.py

Columns:

window,segment,timestamp,address,bus,data_hex

By default we compute timestamp seconds relative to the first CAN message. You can mark a window by start time + duration (seconds), and everything else becomes pre/post.

Requires openpilot’s LogReader on PYTHONPATH; either install openpilot next to this script or run from within your openpilot venv.

Examples

python rlog_to_csv.py –rlog /path/route/rlog2.zst –window-start 58918.188

–window-dur 27.399 –out out.csv

comma_tools.analyzers.rlog_to_csv.main()[source]¶

can_bitwatch.py — Swiss‑army analyzer for CSV dumps of CAN frames with segment labels. Danny/Friday edition. Inputs:

CSV with columns: window,segment,timestamp,address,bus,data_hex

  • segment in {“pre”,”window”,”post”} (case-insensitive)

  • timestamp in seconds (float, absolute); we compute relative to window start for mm:ss.mmm

  • address is hex like “0x027” or decimal; we normalize to int

  • data_hex is 0–8 bytes, MSB-first (e.g., “00 00 00 00 20 02 00 00” or “0000000020020000”)

Outputs (by default to <output_prefix>.*):

  • counts.csv: address × (pre, window, post, delta)

  • per_address.json: per-address notes (unique payload counts per segment; top payloads)

  • bit_edges.csv: all detected bit edges for watched bits, with timings and labels

  • candidates_window_only.csv: bits that toggle only inside the window

  • accel_hunt.csv: results of “3 pulses ~2s each” search (±0.5s tolerance)

Usage:

python can_bitwatch.py –csv in.csv –output-prefix analysis –watch 0x027:B4b5 0x027:B5b1 0x67A:B3b7 0x321:B5b1

Tip

Use together with rlog_to_csv.py to generate the CSV from an rlog.zst.

comma_tools.analyzers.can_bitwatch.parse_hex_bytes(s)[source]¶
Return type:

comma_tools.analyzers.can_bitwatch.msb_label_to_indices(label)[source]¶

Convert “B4b5” (MSB-first bit naming) to (byte_idx, msb_bit, lsb_bit). B<number> b<number>, both 0-indexed. MSB b7..b0. Example: B4b5 -> byte=4, msb=5, lsb=2

Return type:

Tuple[int, int, int]

comma_tools.analyzers.can_bitwatch.global_idx_from_msb(byte_idx, msb_bit)[source]¶
Return type:

int

For each candidate bit, reconstruct its on/off timeline and look for exactly three ~2s high pulses.

comma_tools.analyzers.can_bitwatch.main()[source]¶

CAN Bus Analysis¶

CAN message decoders for automotive analysis.

exception comma_tools.can.decoders.CANDecodingError[source]¶

Bases: Exception

Exception raised when CAN message decoding fails.

class comma_tools.can.decoders.SubaruCANDecoder[source]¶

Bases: object

Decoder for Subaru CAN messages based on DBC specifications

WHEEL_SPEEDS_ADDR = 314¶
CRUISE_BUTTONS_ADDR = 326¶
CRUISE_STATUS_ADDR = 577¶
ES_BRAKE_ADDR = 544¶
BRAKE_PEDAL_ADDR = 313¶
DASHLIGHTS_ADDR = 912¶
static decode_wheel_speeds(data, validate=True)[source]¶

Decode wheel speeds from address 0x13A (314).

Parameters:

  • data (bytes) – 8-byte CAN message payload

  • validate (bool) – Whether to validate decoded values for reasonableness

Return type:

Optional[Dict[str, float]]

Returns:

Dict with wheel speeds in kph/mph, or None if decoding fails

Raises:

CANDecodingError – If validation is enabled and values are unreasonable

static decode_cruise_buttons(data)[source]¶

Decode cruise control buttons from address 0x146 (326).

Parameters:

data (bytes) – 8-byte CAN message payload

Return type:

Optional[Dict[str, bool]]

Returns:

Dict with button states, or None if decoding fails

static decode_cruise_status(data, validate=True)[source]¶

Decode cruise status from address 0x241 (577).

Parameters:

  • data (bytes) – 8-byte CAN message payload

  • validate (bool) – Whether to validate decoded values

Return type:

Optional[Dict[str, Any]]

Returns:

Dict with cruise status, or None if decoding fails

Raises:

CANDecodingError – If validation fails

static decode_es_brake(data)[source]¶

Decode ES_Brake from address 0x220 (544).

Parameters:

data (bytes) – 8-byte CAN message payload

Return type:

Optional[Dict[str, Any]]

Returns:

Dict with brake system status, or None if decoding fails

static decode_blinkers(data)[source]¶

Decode blinker lamp state from Dashlights (0x390).

Parameters:

data (bytes) – 8-byte CAN message payload

Return type:

Optional[Dict[str, bool]]

Returns:

Dict with blinker states, or None if decoding fails

Generic decoder that routes to appropriate decoder based on address.

Parameters:

  • data (bytes) – Message payload

  • validate (bool) – Whether to validate decoded values

Return type:

Optional[Dict[str, Any]]

Returns:

Decoded message data or None if no decoder available

CAN Bit Analysis Library

Unified library for analyzing bit-level changes in CAN message data. Provides both low-level bit manipulation and high-level statistical analysis.

class comma_tools.can.bit_analysis.BitChangeEvent(timestamp, bit_position, old_value, new_value, address)[source]¶

Bases: object

Single bit change event with timing information

new_value: int¶

find_changed_bits(old_data, new_data)[source]¶

Find bit positions that changed between two payloads.

Parameters:

  • old_data (bytes) – Previous message payload

  • new_data (bytes) – Current message payload

Return type:

List[int]

Returns:

List of bit positions (0-based) that changed

payload_to_u64(payload, endian='little')[source]¶

Convert payload to 64-bit int for bit operations.

Parameters:

  • payload (bytes) – CAN message payload (up to 8 bytes)

  • endian (str) – Byte order (“little” or “big”)

Return type:

int

Returns:

64-bit integer representation

get_bit_value(data, bit_position)[source]¶

Extract single bit value from data.

Parameters:

  • data (Union[bytes, int]) – Either bytes payload or integer representation

  • bit_position (int) – 0-based bit position (0 = LSB)

Return type:

int

Returns:

Bit value (0 or 1)

compute_change_stats(messages)[source]¶

Compute bit change statistics across message sequence.

Parameters:

messages (List[CanMessage]) – List of CAN messages (should be sorted by timestamp)

Return type:

Optional[BitChangeStats]

Returns:

BitChangeStats object or None if insufficient data

track_bit_toggles(messages, watched_bits=None)[source]¶

Track toggle timestamps for specific bits.

Parameters:

  • messages (List[CanMessage]) – List of CAN messages (should be sorted by timestamp)

  • watched_bits (Optional[List[int]]) – Specific bit positions to track (None = track all)

Return type:

Dict[int, List[float]]

Returns:

Dict mapping bit_position -> list of toggle timestamps

analyze_multi_address(messages_by_address)[source]¶

Analyze bit changes across multiple CAN addresses.

Parameters:

messages_by_address (Dict[int, List[CanMessage]]) – Dict mapping address -> list of messages

Return type:

Dict[int, BitChangeStats]

Returns:

Dict mapping address -> BitChangeStats

find_bits_active_in_window(messages, window_start, window_end)[source]¶

Find bits that toggle only within a specific time window.

Parameters:

  • messages (List[CanMessage]) – List of CAN messages

  • window_start (float) – Start timestamp of window

  • window_end (float) – End timestamp of window

Return type:

List[int]

Returns:

List of bit positions that toggle only in the window

Detect specific bit edge events with full context.

Parameters:

  • watched_bits (List[int]) – Bit positions to monitor for edges

Return type:

List[BitChangeEvent]

Returns:

List of BitChangeEvent objects

Monitors¶

Utilities¶

OpenPilot environment setup utilities.

This module provides common functions for setting up the OpenPilot environment, managing dependencies, and preparing the Python path for OpenPilot tools.

Locate the root directory that contains the openpilot checkout.

Return type:

Path

Return type:

Path

Prepare the Python environment for OpenPilot tools.

Return type:

None

Ensure required Python packages are available.

Return type:

None

comma_tools.utils.openpilot_utils.ensure_cloudlog_stub()[source]¶

Create a stub for openpilot’s cloudlog module to avoid import errors.

Load external modules required for OpenPilot analysis.

comma_tools.utils.openpilot_utils.add_openpilot_to_path(repo_root=None)[source]¶

Add OpenPilot to Python path (alternative approach used by rlog_to_csv).

Visualization¶

Plotting utilities for automotive data visualization.

Bases: object

Utility class for creating speed timeline plots with event highlighting.

Initialize the plotter with default figure size.

plot_speed_timeline(speed_data, target_speed_events=None, target_speed_min=55.0, target_speed_max=56.0, output_filename='speed_timeline.png', title='Vehicle Speed Timeline - Extracted from Wheel Speed CAN Messages')[source]¶

Create a plot showing speed over time with target events highlighted.

Parameters:

  • speed_data (List[Dict[str, Any]]) – List of dicts with ‘timestamp’ and ‘speed_mph’ keys

  • target_speed_events (Optional[List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – List of events with ‘start_time’ and ‘end_time’ keys

  • target_speed_min (float) – Minimum target speed for highlighting

  • target_speed_max (float) – Maximum target speed for highlighting

  • output_filename (str) – Name of the output file

  • title (str) – Plot title

Return type:

str

Returns:

Path to the saved plot file

plot_signal_timeline(signal_data, signal_name, events=None, output_filename=None, title=None)[source]¶

Create a generic signal timeline plot with event highlighting.

Parameters:

  • signal_data (List[Dict[str, Any]]) – List of dicts with ‘timestamp’ and signal value keys

  • signal_name (str) – Name of the signal to plot (key in signal_data dicts)

  • events (Optional[List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – List of events to highlight with ‘timestamp’ key

  • output_filename (Optional[str]) – Name of the output file (auto-generated if None)

  • title (Optional[str]) – Plot title (auto-generated if None)

Return type:

str

Returns:

Path to the saved plot file

plot_multi_signal_timeline(signals, output_filename='multi_signal_timeline.png', title='Multi-Signal Timeline', subplot_height=3)[source]¶

Create a multi-subplot plot for multiple signals.

Parameters:

  • signals (Dict[str, List[Dict[str, Any]]]) – Dict mapping signal names to their data lists

  • output_filename (str) – Name of the output file

  • title (str) – Overall plot title

  • subplot_height (float) – Height of each subplot

Return type:

str

Returns:

Path to the saved plot file
